importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article highlights the ongoing annual issue of poor air quality during Diwali, particularly in New Delhi, where air quality reached a hazardous level on this day due to fireworks and pollution.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from October 21 to 23 covers the Diwali festival period, during which fireworks and seasonal pollution peak, leading to sustained hazardous air quality in New Delhi and surrounding areas.

keyTakeAways: New Delhi’s air quality index (AQI) reached 442 on October 21, 2025, making it the most hazardous city in the world according to IQAir.
The AQI in New Delhi was over 59 times the World Health Organization’s recommended annual PM2.5 guideline, with PM2.5 concentrations posing serious health risks.
India’s Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) rated the air quality as 'very poor' with an AQI of 350, indicating dangerous levels of pollution.
Fireworks used during Diwali, especially outside the permitted three-hour window, significantly contributed to air pollution.
The Supreme Court allowed the use of 'green crackers' for limited periods, but widespread violations occurred, increasing pollution.
New Delhi and neighboring districts face persistent winter smog due to cold air trapping pollutants from traffic, industry, and agriculture.
Historical smog events, such as in November 2024 when the AQI peaked at over 1,700, show recurring and severe air quality crises.
Lahore, Pakistan, had an AQI of 234, the second-highest globally, due to cross-border pollution from Indian Punjab and agricultural fires.
Pakistani authorities have activated emergency measures, including anti-smog guns and restrictions on farm fires and vehicles, to counter pollution.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the Diwali festival in October 2025, New Delhi’s air quality deteriorated to a hazardous level, reaching an AQI of 442—the highest in the world—due to widespread fireworks and seasonal pollution. The concentration of PM2.5 exceeded 59 times the WHO’s recommended annual limit, with the Central Pollution Control Board classifying the air as 'very poor.' Although the Supreme Court permitted limited use of environmentally safer green crackers, violations led to excessive pollution. The situation is exacerbated by cold winter weather that traps pollutants from traffic, industry, and agriculture. The crisis is not isolated; Lahore, Pakistan, also faced high pollution (AQI of 234), indicating transboundary air pollution from Indian Punjab. Authorities in both countries have responded with emergency measures, including anti-smog guns and restrictions, underscoring the need for regional cooperation to combat air pollution.
title: Diwali provokes ‘hazardous’ alert over New Delhi air quality
